Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Story: It was Saturday afternoon, and I was curled up on the couch with my boyfriend, trying to comfort him after he’d received some harsh feedback at work. He looked so defeated, and I could feel his need for reassurance and support. I wanted to be fully present for him, to listen and hold him, but my phone buzzed with a message from my mom: “Haven’t heard from you this weekend. Everything okay?” I knew my parents worried if I didn’t check in, and I could already imagine my mom’s anxious voice if I didn’t reply soon. My boyfriend glanced at me, his eyes searching for comfort, while my phone vibrated again. I felt torn—my parents expected me to keep in touch, but my boyfriend needed me right now. My heart raced as I tried to decide who needed me more in this moment, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
